FILE: cm420433v11.0.txt
DYAD: GAMBIA - SENEGAL
RIVALRY: RIV1049
DISPUTE(S): MID2616 MID1384 

PSNOTES: 
PS-LAST-CHANGED: 20180702
PS-LAST-CHECKED: 20180914

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

MID2616

TERRMID: MID2616 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID2616 from Gibler 2018, Gambia and Senegal did not have a territory MID because the territorial boundary was not disputed. Senegal believed it was losing revenue due to Gambian smuggling. A Sengalese police officer was detained in Gambia after chasing smugglers, and was later released. Senegal raided two villages in Gambia about two weeks later. Gambia protested at the invasion of its territory. 

TERRLINK: MID2616 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID2616 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID2616 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID2616 3 -- not civil war 
CIVWARMID-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID2616 coded not civil war because this involved bandits, not militarized rebels. 

CIVWARLINK: MID2616 3 -- not civil war link
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID2616 3 -- not coup 
COUPMID-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: 

COUPLINK: MID2616 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID2616 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID1384

TERRMID: MID1384 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID1384 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: MID1384 from Gibler 2018, Gambia and Senegal did not have a territory MID because the territorial boundary was not disputed. Senegal violently arrested twenty farmers in Gambia, and Gambia protested because their border was crossed. Senegal accepted responsibility, and there was no attempt to change borders. Coded not territory because the territorial boundaries between Senegal and Gambia were not disputed. 

TERRLINK: MID1384 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID1384 1 -- certain

MID4351

TERRMID: MID4351 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID4351 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID4351 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID4351 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID4351 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID4351 from Gibler 2018, in 2002 Senegal reinforced its border to prevent rebels in Gambia from crossing into Senegal. Coded civil war MID because this was connected to militarized rebels in Gambia. 

CIVWARLINK: MID4351 3 -- not civil war link
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain
CIVWARLINK-NOTES:

COUPMID-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES:

COUPLINK-CER: MID4351 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

MID4 2002-2010:

MID4351
rivalry=420433 nationa=SENEGAL nationb=GAMBIA MID4351 20020707-20020707 
 revtype1a=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2a=NOT APPLICABLE fatala=NONE fatalpa=0 lhosta=DISPLAY OF FORCE 
 revtype1b=NOT APPLICABLE revtype2b=NOT APPLICABLE fatalb=NONE fatalpb=0
lhostb=NO MILITARIZED ACTION 

After extending operations against the Casamance rebels to the border with Gambia, Senegal deployed additional military forces along the Gambian border to prevent Casamance rebels entering Senegal from bases in Gambia. First day of dispute was on 7/7/2002 and last day of dispute was on 7/7/2002.

RIVNOTES: 

NARRATIVE-CM:
Gambian border police detained a Senegalese policeman and customs official near the border on January 14, 1971, and Senegalese troops attacked two villages in Gambia on January 31, 1971. Senegalese troops attacked villages in the Jokadu district of Gambia in July 1974. President Dawda Jawara of Gambia suppressed an attempted rebellion on October 27, 1980, during which the deputy commander of the Gambian paramilitary force, Emmanuuel Mahoney, was killed. President Jawara banned two opposition groups, *Movement for Justice in Africa* - *Gambia* (MOJA-Gambia) and the *Gambia Socialist Revolutionary Party* (GSRP) headed by Pingon Georges, for their involvement in the attempted rebellion on October 30, 1980. President Jawara requested military assistance from Senegal, and some 150 Senegalese troops were deployed in the country from October 31 to November 7, 1980. Members of the Gambian paramilitary force rebelled against the government beginning on July 29, 1981. The *Supreme Revolutionary Council *(SRC) headed by Kukli Samba Sabyang took control of the government on July 30, 1981. President Jawara, who was in London at the time of the rebellion, requested the military intervention of Senagalese troops on July 30, 1981. Some 2,700 Senegalese troops intervened in support of President Jawara beginning on August 1, 1981. President Jawara declared a state-of-emergency on August 2, 1981. Government troops and Senegalese troops suppressed the rebellion on August 5, 1981. Some 800 individuals, including nine Senegalese soldiers, were killed during the rebellion. Senegal and Gambia signed an agreement to form a confederation on December 17, 1981, and the *Confederation of Senegal and Gambia* was formally established on February 1, 1982. Senegal withdrew 300 troops from Gambia on August 19, 1989. The *Confederation of Senegal and Gambia *was dissolved on September 30, 1989. Gambian and Senegalese representatives signed a treaty of friendship and cooperation on January 8, 1991. Senegal closed its border with Gambia. President Dawda Jawara of Gambia requested the mediation of President Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia on February 2, 1994.

SOURCES-CM: 
*Africa Research Bulletin* (ARB), November 1-30, 1981, December 1-31, 1981; Brecher and Wilkenfeld, 1997, 458-459, 462; *Foreign Broadcast Information Service* (FBIS), February 3, 1994; Jessup, 1998, 225-226; Tilemma, 1991, 65, 66, 67-69.

NARRATIVE-CR:

SOURCES-CR:

SOURCES: Gibler, D.M. 2018. Militarized Interstate Dispute Narratives, 1816-2010. Langham, MD: Rowman and Littlefield.
